That's why we love Austin

We don't properly have a music scene. There are tons of music niches, metal mostly. Indie bands play frequently, but there's not an event culture yet. People hang out outside, don't buy merch, complain about ticket costs. It's difficult. Also, big events are killing small venues. It's hard.

Something about these high altitude towns where people get adjusted and routine. I dunno.

I don't know what to say. BogotÃ¡ feels that way. We don't actually play in our country that much. It's sad. I'll be reading the articles.
Dude...

I am ok here. Many are not. We are a transgender positive community and the current shift in politics has everyone on edge. No one knows anything yet but it works toward more public abandonment, not supportive community building we desperately need here.
Simply because they ARE modern day Albuquerque.
These kats KNOW Albuquerque. Comes out in everything they do and write. Again, without even trying to do so. They are one of my favs here. Truly.
https://open.substack.com/pub/joesmithstringer/p/the-maddening-genius-of-nara-visa?r=2ihwss&utm_medium=ios
I like this one. I wrote it about two of our most beloved humans in the scene. I think they captured the first 25 years in our new century in Albuquerque very well (without even trying to do so).
https://open.substack.com/pub/joesmithstringer/p/the-gral-brothers-volume-3-a-25-year?r=2ihwss&utm_medium=ios

Post Covid: everyone is home by 8pm; in bed by 10. Some shows donâ€™t start til 9. Nobody goes out. Restaurants and independent retail shops are closing. Public seems checked OUT. But everybody goes through the motions and will tell you itâ€™s all good. Everything is fine.

The Albuquerque scene???

Was once RULED by metal. Metal everywhere and every damn thing; it became a very popular touring spot in the 80â€™s and 90â€™s because of metal. Indigenous and popular hiphop had a killer underground scene here in the mid 2000â€™s all the way up to ehâ€¦..2012-2015. Ish.

Punk was huge here just before covid and the DIY scene was world famous. All of it gone now.

Nothing but breweries and singer songwriters killing themselves for a couple of bucks. Venues pay nothing to very little. And they get away with it due to the sheer number of artists we have here. We have a LOT!!

But the beauty here. Goes largely and sadly ignored. Propped up against the Sandia Peak, we get TWO sunsets every night when the light bounces off the rock. Most folks glass over the beauty here to point out all the things we donâ€™t have.

We may be on the brink of a culture shift here where smaller venues and homes (like mine) become intimate listening spaces. While we wait for landlords and citizens to re-occupy their agency. Iâ€™m building a listening schedule now and we have a few promising joints in Nob Hill (the trendy area; next to UNM). 

Everything is wide open here. Artists who struggle want their validation in the form of a public support who cannot recognize them.
Artists who thrive, get OUT QUICK, and usually guts the entire town for about 6-12 months. Feels like a minor league farm here at times for musicians. And art. As such, the public views it as minor also. Ignorable.

Itâ€™s a love hate relationship for sure. Everyone struggles for identity here yet we donâ€™t have the population density to support segregation and stuck mindsets. I fear we are on the brink of an upcoming gentrification and itâ€™s gonna get violent. Poverty is king here and frustrations are literally pouring into the streets of downtown. Venues are stuck in the 90â€™s; public is justifiably AFRAID to go out at night; landlords are absent; city officials are absent. Everyone seems absent here. It has taken a toll on our human arts scene. 

Point blank: our scene is unsupported here. Despite the wide array of genre and evolution of high desert music.
Is there something you've wrote that can help us contextualize the Albuquerque scene? Would love to know more.
As an artist, I guess thatâ€™s my Albuquerque. Itâ€™s weird and broke here but we have a unique music community (very accepting). Glad to hear thatâ€™s your Austin. ğŸ¤˜ğŸ¼ğŸ’«

Buffalo Ironworks is a cool club, esp in warm weather because thereâ€™s a garage door right by the stage that opens onto an alleyway with table and chairs. Very cool. 

Town Ballroom has a great following and is one of my favorite places to see bands because of the various levels of places to stand. 

Electric City is new and pretty cool. People can reserve tables or couch areas for extra $. I was only there once.
